intro: Rubus ellipticus var. incisus, commonly known as the narrow-leaf blackberry, is a species of brambles native to the Pacific Northwest of the United States. It is characterized by its elliptical, sharply toothed leaves and thorny stems. The plant produces small, aggregate fruits that are typically dark purple to black when ripe. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland edges and stream banks. The species is valued for its edible berries and its role in local ecosystems.
